did.unittitle: Relacion General... de las plazas de Oran y Mazalquivir
did.abstract:
The Spanish military engineer Antonio de Gaver oversaw the construction of castles, forts, and other military installations in Spain and on the Spanish-Portuguese border beginning as early as 1719, and he was a prolific cartographer and surveyor.
The Gaver manuscript ("Relacion general...de las plazes de Oran, Mazalquivir su importancia, actual estado de defensa de ambas, sus castillos, fuertes, quarteles, y de mas edificios militares con una brebe noticia de su conquista, perdida, recuperacion vecindario, consumos, guarnicion, clero, ministerio, govierno militar, politico, y de mas circunstancias notables") is a thorough study of military installations in several fortified towns in North Africa, including Oran, Mazalquivir, Ceuta, and Melilla, with notes on their population, government, and history, as well as a more extensive a history of Oran during the years of spanish domination, 1505-1541. Bound neatly in vellum, the volumes contain other material of historical interest, including a brief description of the kingdom of Tremecen in North Africa, a synopsis of the Franco-Spanish treaty of 1761, and two poems by Don Sebastian Fernandez de Medrano. The volume is accompanied by a manuscript map, Plano del puerto y plaza de Oran y Castillo Mazalquivir.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Spanish military engineer Antonio de Gaver oversaw the construction of castles, forts, and other military installations in Spain and on the Spanish-Portuguese border beginning as early as 1719, and he was a prolific cartographer and surveyor. Gaver is also recorded as director of the Academy of Mathematics of Oran in 1739, one of the Barbary ports in North Africa that had been the target of repeated Spanish incursions for over two centuries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Gaver manuscript is a thorough study of military installations in several fortified towns in North Africa, including Oran, Mazalquivir, Ceuta, and Melilla, with notes on their population, government, and history, as well as a more extensive a history of Oran during the years of spanish domination, 1505-1541. Bound neatly in vellum, the volumes contain other material of historical interest, including a brief description of the kingdom of Tremecen in North Africa, a synopsis of the Franco-Spanish treaty of 1761, and two poems by Don Sebastian Fernandez de Medrano. The volume is accompanied by a manuscript map, Plano del puerto y plaza de Oran y Castillo Mazalquivir.

The full title of the work is Relacion General Dividida en nuebe Secciones en que se manifiesta la consistencia de las Plazas de Oran, y Mazalquivir su Ymportancia actual estado de efense de ambas, sus castillos, Fuertes, Quarteles, y de mas Edificies Militares con una brebe noticia de su conquista, perdid, Consumos, Guarnicion, Clero, Ministerio, Govierno, Militar, Politico, y de mas cicumstancias notables, en 1773."

prefercite.p: Cite as: Antonio de Gaver, Relacion General... de las Plazas de Oran y Mazalquivir, American Philosophical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Joel R. Poinsett, 1820. The map was acquired from A. Asher and Co., July 2004 (M2004-27).

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: The manuscript map, Plano del puerto y plaza de Oran y Castillo Mazalquivir, is housed in oversized storage.

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: This manuscript collection falls outside the geographic scope of the Early American guide (British North America and the United States before 1840). It may be of interest to scholars interested in global history, international relations, imperialism, or the U.S. in the world.
